properties.description: The dumping of 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor by American colonists led by Samuel Adams and the Sons of Liberty.
The British Parliament's passage of the Tea Act, granting the British East India Company a monopoly on tea sales in the American colonies.
Participation of working-class individuals in colonial protests.
The lack of French financial or military support to the American colonies prior to 1776.
The presence of non-merchant leaders in numerous revolutionary committees.
King George III's rejection of the Olive Branch Petition.
The Tea Act imposed taxation without colonial representation in Parliament, violating fundamental principles of self-governance.
Creation of economic pressure on local merchants and ideological mobilization around constitutional principles.
Organized resistance by groups like the Sons of Liberty channeling colonial discontent.
The American Revolution was primarily caused by the Tea Act of 1773 due to its violation of constitutional principles of self-governance, leading to ideological mobilization and organized resistance.

The Tea Act imposed taxation without representation, creating economic pressure and ideological mobilization, which groups like the Sons of Liberty channeled into organized resistance, culminating in direct action against British property.
The American Revolution was primarily driven by colonial merchants' economic interests, with wealthy merchants manipulating popular sentiment to protect smuggling operations and avoid British taxes.
key_predictions: disproportionate merchant leadership in revolutionary activities
focus on trade policy over representation issues

properties.description: Colonial elites deliberately manufactured popular outrage to advance their own political ambitions, with revolutionary rhetoric concentrated among the educated elite.
key_predictions: revolutionary rhetoric would be concentrated among the educated elite rather than emerging organically from popular sentiment

properties.description: French agents and financial support were the primary drivers of colonial rebellion, seeking to weaken their British rivals.
key_predictions: early French involvement and financial backing before 1775

properties.description: Samuel Adams, a principal organizer of the American Revolution.
properties.name: Samuel Adams
properties.intentions: mobilize mass resistance against British authority
properties.beliefs: British rule fundamentally violated colonial rights
properties.constraints: need to maintain legitimacy and avoid alienating moderate colonists
properties.capabilities: extensive political networks and persuasive rhetoric

properties.description: Group of American colonists who organized resistance against British authority.
properties.name: Sons of Liberty
properties.intentions: channel discontent into organized resistance; direct action against British property

properties.description: Governor of Massachusetts, representing British authority.
properties.name: Governor Thomas Hutchinson
properties.beliefs: colonists were ungrateful subjects who needed firm governance
properties.constraints: limited military resources and the need to maintain order
properties.capabilities: formal governmental authority but limited practical enforcement power

properties.description: British Monarch during the American Revolution.
properties.name: King George III
properties.intentions: maintain imperial control and extract revenue
properties.beliefs: colonies as subordinate territories that existed to benefit Britain
properties.constraints: distance, communication delays, and competing European threats
properties.capabilities: British military and navy but limited by costs and logistics of transatlantic warfare

properties.description: The Royal Navy's dominance of the Atlantic.
The spread of Enlightenment philosophy about natural rights and self-governance.
The 3,000-mile separation between Britain and America, causing communication delays of 6-12 weeks.
The colonies' growing economic self-sufficiency by the 1770s.
Colonial pamphlets explicitly arguing against taxation without representation.
Widespread colonial support for resistance across different economic classes.
Formal declarations by the Continental Congress citing constitutional violations.
Samuel Adams' documented correspondence showing deliberate organization of the Tea Party.
Hutchinson's letters to London revealing his failed attempts to prevent escalation.

properties.intention: mobilize mass resistance against British authority
maintain imperial control and extract revenue

properties.source_text_quote: The Royal Navy's dominance of the Atlantic initially prevented foreign assistance to the colonies and enabled British force projection, constraining colonial options for resistance.
properties.constraint_factors: prevented foreign assistance, enabled British force projection

properties.source_text_quote: The spread of Enlightenment philosophy about natural rights and self-governance provided the ideological framework that enabled colonists to justify resistance as legitimate.
The colonies' growing economic self-sufficiency by the 1770s enabled them to contemplate independence as economically viable.
Colonial pamphlets explicitly arguing against taxation without representation
Widespread colonial support across different economic classes
The Continental Congress's formal declarations citing constitutional violations
Working-class participation in protests refutes the elite manipulation theory
Absence of French support before 1776 refutes the external influence theory
Non-merchant leadership in many revolutionary committees challenges the economic self-interest theory
Samuel Adams' documented correspondence shows deliberate organization of the Tea Party
Samuel Adams' documented correspondence shows deliberate organization of the Tea Party
Hutchinson's letters to London reveal his failed attempts to prevent escalation
George III's rejection of the Olive Branch Petition demonstrates his intentional choice for military suppression
